   <lt;mi>gt;A<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt;
   <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} q \le A k_d^\alpha
   n_d^{1-\alpha }. \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (20)
   The first-order conditions for capital and labor are
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;A<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">gt;
   <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \xi (p,q) \alpha A
   {\left(\frac{n_d}{k_d}\right)}^{1-\alpha }=r,
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (21)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;A<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">gt;
   <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt; <lt;mi>gt;α<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \xi (p,q) (1-\alpha ) A
   {\left(\frac{k_d}{n_d}\right)}^{\alpha }=w,
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (22)
   where
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\xi (p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is the lagrange multiplier on the production constraint. By taking the
   ratio between these two first-order conditions, it is easy to see that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\frac{k_d}{n_d}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is the same in any trading post. Then,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\xi (p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is equal for all
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$(p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Thus, it is going to be called ξ from now onward.
   Using the two first-order conditions, maximized profits can be written
   as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;π<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \pi (p,q)= \phi (\theta
   (p,q)) p q-\xi q. \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (23)
   Since firms can choose between different markets
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$(p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , all potentially active ones must give the same profits. Furthermore,
   free entry implies that such profits must be zero: if profits were
   positive, there would be infinite posts and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi
   (\theta (p,q))=0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , which contradicts that profits are positive. Thus, any submarket
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p,q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   visited by positive number of buyers has
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mspace
   width="17.07182pt">gt;<lt;/mspace>gt; <lt;mtext>gt;and<lt;/mtext>gt; <lt;mspace
   width="17.07182pt">gt;<lt;/mspace>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation*} \phi (\theta (p,q))
   p-\xi \le 0 \hspace{17.07182pt} \text{and} \hspace{17.07182pt} \theta
   (p,q)\ge 0, \end{equation*}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   where the two inequalities hold with complementary slackness. That is,
   if
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta (p,q)) p<lt;\xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , then
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta
   (p,q)= 0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   because no trading post would open. If a submarket has trading posts (
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta
   (p,q)>gt; 0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ), then
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta (p,q)) p=\xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Since
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi \le 1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , a necessary condition for a submarket to be active is that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p\ge \xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Otherwise,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta (p,q)) p<lt;\xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   for any θ; thus, submarkets with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p<lt;\xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   never attract any trading posts. Finally, if a submarket does not
   attract any buyers, then
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta (p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   can be arbitrary as long as it is such that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta (p,q)) p\le
   \xi$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (see Menzio, Shi, and Sun [132]2013 for a game theoretic “trembling
   hand” explanation). For markets with no buyers, I assume that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta (p,q)) p=\xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   as long as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p\ge \xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Restricting this off-equilibrium belief to a strict equality has no
   implications for the equilibrium but it is helpful because it implies
   that for
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p\ge \xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the function
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta (p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   solves
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \phi (\theta (p,q))
   p=\xi . \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (24)
   As a result, function θ has the properties in the following lemma.

   Lemma 1.For
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p\ge \xi$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
     * 1.
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta
       (p,q)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       is differentiable,
     * 2.
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\frac{\partial \theta (p,q)}{\partial
       p}>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       ,
     * 3.
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\frac{\partial \theta (p,q)}{\partial
       q}=0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       .

   The proof in the Online Appendix follows from Equation ([133]24) and
   the properties of the function ϕ. Since the function θ does not depend
   on q, from now on, it will be denoted
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta (p)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   . The intuition why θ does not depend on q is that, since the
   production function has constant returns to scale and input prices are
   taken as given, production increases proportionally with costs. Then,
   for profits to be equal to 0 (and hence independent of q), ϕ and
   thereby θ have to also be independent of q.

   Finally, it is worth discussing the issue that trading posts pay the
   input markets irrespective of whether they are in a match and make
   revenues. For this, it is necessary to assume that the law of large
   numbers holds within each submarket so that there is perfect ex post
   redistribution of revenues between trading posts in the same submarket.
   It should be noticed that this ex post redistribution does not require
   firms to commit to an explicit insurance scheme between them because a
   single firm can open a large number of trading posts. See Menzio, Shi,
   and Sun ([134]2013) for a similar discussion.

1.4 Equilibrium

   It is convenient to first define equilibrium assuming that agents honor
   all obligations given the limits B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , and then find the information and enforcement frictions that make
   this behavior optimal.

   Before defining an equilibrium, it is useful to pick a numeraire.
   Equation ([135]24) pins down a relationship between θ and p up to a
   value for revenues per unit of production ξ. ξ is free and can be
   normalized.[136]30 As a normalization, ξ is equal to the equilibrium
   value of ϕ. This implies
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p=1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   in the equilibrium submarket as is immediate from equation
   ([137]24).[138]31

   Below there are formal definitions of a recursive monetary and a
   nonmonetary equilibrium given a debt limit function. In a monetary
   equilibrium, it is also necessary to pin down the money growth rate, or
   equivalently the return on bonds v as an exogenous policy instrument.
   The definition below uses the latter as the policy instrument.[139]32

   Definition 2.Monetary equilibrium assuming no default

   Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;∃<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B(p,\Omega ,\exists )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi
   mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∃<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}(p,\Omega ,\exists )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   denote the credit limit functions where Ω is a vector of aggregate
   state variables: the aggregate capital and money stocks
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;K<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$K\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$M\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , as well as possible shocks (such as a technology shock A, a shock to
   the matching function, money growth, a preference shock). Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi
   mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v(\Omega )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   be the government policy. A monetary equilibrium ∃ is composed of a
   value function V and policy rules
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;c<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$c,k^{\prime
   },m^{\prime }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$a^{\prime },q$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   for the household as function of
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$a,k,m,\Omega$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , a function
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta (p;\Omega )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and prices
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$w,r,p_m,v$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , measure of firms f, input demands per firm
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$k_d$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$n_d$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , revenues per unit of production ξ, all functions of Ω, such that:
     * 1. Household: The household's decisions and value function solve
       the problem in Section [140]1.2
     * 2. Firms:
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$k_d$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       ,
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$n_d$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       , and
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta (p;\Omega )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
       <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       satisfy equations ([141]21), ([142]22), and ([143]24) with
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ξ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Ω<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
       <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\xi =\phi (\theta
       (1;\Omega ))$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       .[144]33
     * 3. The liquid assets, and the inputs markets clear with
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
       <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       :
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo
       linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       linebreak="goodbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Δ<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mspace width="17.07182pt">gt;<lt;/mspace>gt; <lt;msup>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mspace width="17.07182pt">gt;<lt;/mspace>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo
       linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mspace
       width="17.07182pt">gt;<lt;/mspace>gt; <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;K<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation*} m^{\prime
       }=M+\Delta m, \hspace{17.07182pt} a^{\prime }=0,
       \hspace{17.07182pt} f n_d=1, \hspace{17.07182pt} f k_d=K.
       \end{equation*}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       Furthermore, households and firms search in the same market:
       calling
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q^d$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       the quantity chosen by the household and
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;s<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q^s$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       that chosen by firms,
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo
       linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;s<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
       <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} q^d=q^s.
       \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       (25)
     * 4. Aggregate and individual state variables are consistent:
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;K<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
       <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$k=K$<lt;/annotation>gt;
       <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       ,
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
       <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$m=M$<lt;/annotation>gt;
       <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       .
     * 5. The exogenous stochastic shocks follow Markovian processes of
       order 1.

   Notice that equation ([145]25) implies that households' purchases are
   equal to firms' sales
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;d<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;s<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi (\theta ) q^d= \phi (\theta ) f
   q^s$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . This is because the matching function has the property that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi /\phi
   =\theta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta =f$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   given that households are of measure 1.

   Definition 3.Nonmonetary equilibrium assuming no default

   A nonmonetary equilibrium is the same but with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m=0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and with v endogenous.

   Besides the fact that market clearing occurs with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   in a monetary equilibrium and with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m=0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   in a nonmonetary one, the other difference is that a monetary
   equilibrium depends on a policy for the price of bonds v. Instead, in a
   nonmonetary equilibrium, v is pinned down. Intuitively, v is not
   endogenously determined in a monetary equilibrium because the supply of
   money is exogenous. In a nonmonetary equilibrium, the value of the
   supply of money is zero so v must adjust endogenously to ensure that
   agents do not demand excess liquidity.

   As it is well known, monetary economies also have nonrecursive monetary
   equilibria but this paper focuses on recursive ones.

Imperfect monitoring and limited commitment

   The household has to honor the debt, the ToT agreed ex ante in the
   competitive search protocol, and the insurance mechanism. Here, I show
   that all these contracts are honored under the limited commitment that
   is enforceable with imperfect monitoring, which is required to make
   money essential as pointed out by Kocherlakota ([146]1998) and Wallace
   ([147]2010). Agents can renege on any of the contracts mentioned above
   but the commitment is endogenized introducing participation constraints
   following Thomas and Worrall ([148]1988), Kehoe and Levine ([149]1993),
   and Alvarez and Jermann ([150]2000) among others.
   There are two assumptions, which, although stated in the initial
   description of the set-up, it is worth repeating as they are key here.
     * (a) Agents caught red handed reneging one of their contracts pay
       their period obligations and lose access to any form of endogenous
       commitment. That agents pay their obligations if caught makes the
       value of default and being caught always lower than the value of
       honoring all obligations. This is a key assumption to sustain full
       insurance with imperfect monitoring.
     * (b) Agents must provide proof of means before entering a submarket.
       Without proof of means, one could pretend to be cash rich and go
       for a submarket with q very large, and then default at the moment
       of paying.

   With the two assumptions, the constructed strategies with full
   insurance, predetermined ToT, and credit with spending limits B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   as in Definitions [151]1 and 2 are incentive compatible, and, thus, are
   part of an equilibrium microfounded by imperfect monitoring and limited
   commitment.[152]34 A detailed description of the off-equilibrium
   problems in case of default is included in Online Appendix C. However,
   the key intuition for the proposition below is simple and does not
   require reading the appendix: because of assumption (a), monitored
   default is always strictly worse than no default. As a result, it is
   always possible to find monitoring probabilities high enough, but
   smaller than one, such that it is incentive compatible to honor all
   obligations. The result is formalized in Proposition [153]1.

   Proposition 1.Equilibrium with endogenous obligations

   Take a solution that satisfies Equilibrium Definition [154]2 or [155]3
   given bounded B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there are probabilities
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;T<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;o<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;T<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_{ToT}, p_b, p_f<lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   such that there are no incentives to default. The probabilities tend to
   1 as B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   tend to ∞.

   Proposition [156]1 states that the decentralization with bounded limits
   B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   satisfies the incentive constraints with imperfect monitoring. So there
   are no incentives to default under these limits. Notice that this
   approach does not restrict attention exclusively to the “not too tight”
   limits of Alvarez and Jermann ([157]2000), that is, those where the
   participation constraints hold with equality. As in Bethune, Hu, and
   Rocheteau ([158]2018), this approach also allows for lower limits where
   some or all the conditions hold with strict inequality. Why would the
   market restrict credit below the highest possible one? Bethune, Hu, and
   Rocheteau ([159]2018) show that tighter limits than the “not too tight”
   ones are consistent with perfect Bayesian equilibrium. In particular,
   Bethune, Hu, and Rocheteau ([160]2018) show that if firms follow a
   strategy that punishes default up to some limit, there are no
   incentives to deviate and offer higher
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   or B: any larger debt would be defaulted on because, under the
   equilibrium strategy, there would be no punishment from the
   other firms.

   Besides the fact that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B must be below the “not too tight” ones, a limitation to their
   shape comes from the fact that the buyer is anonymous, so
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B should be functions of variables that are easily observable to
   the seller: hence in this paper, I rule out limits that are functions
   of the individual state variables. In Section 2.2.3, they are functions
   of the aggregate state variables and of p, which is known by the seller
   and does not preclude the anonymity of the buyer.

   That
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B are flexible within the upper bound is convenient and later some
   examples are considered. Yet, the microfoundation is not
   inconsequential. For instance, it matters for monetary policy: moving
   the interest rate
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/v-1$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the value functions change and, holding the probabilities constant,
   it may be necessary to change B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   in order not to violate the incentive constraints. This has
   implications for optimal policy, see Berentsen, Camera, and Waller
   ([161]2007), Araujo and Hu ([162]2018), Gomis-Porqueras and Sanches
   ([163]2013), and Lotz and Zhang ([164]2016).

   As mentioned, firms have incentives to default too but the resulting
   constraints can be ignored by assuming enough, albeit imperfect firm
   monitoring. This is explained next. Firms have incentives to default on
   the ToT (if p is too low and q too high) and on the payment to the
   inputs
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$wn+rk$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . It follows that given the monitoring probability, all is needed to
   avoid firms default is a lower bound on market tightness θ. This is
   because p is decreasing in θ while q and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$wn+rk$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   are increasing in θ. So a low θ brings all the aforementioned
   incentives to default. However, submarkets with low market tightness
   are also ruled out by households' default incentives.[165]35 It follows
   that if there is enough firm monitoring so that the constraint on θ
   that comes from the incentives of the firms is looser than the one that
   comes from the incentives of the hosueholds, one can solve the model
   ignoring the constraint of the firm. Since the emphasis in this paper
   is on the household, I make this assumption and only focus on the
   incentive constraints of the household. However, it is worth noting
   that one cannot simply assume perfect firm monitoring. In that case,
   there would be scope for a firm to become a market maker that collects
   all the money from the buyers before the matching process, and then use
   the proceedings to pay the trading posts that are successful. If that
   was possible, then the market maker could exploit the law of large
   numbers and ask just enough money to finance the determinisitic number
   of matches, see Faig and Huangfu ([166]2007). Instead, without the
   market maker, there is more money demand because buyers can only use
   their own liquidity in a match and so each buyer needs more money or
   credit than with the market maker. One final worry is that when the
   monitoring probability of the households tends to 1, for the incentive
   constraints of the firm to be looser than the one of the household, the
   monitoring probability of the firm must go to 1 as well. In such cases,
   the market planner becomes incentive feasible. However, its presence
   becomes irrelevant because as per Proposition [167]1, with perfect
   monitoring, any level of obligation is enforceable. And it is shown
   later that in such a case, money is not essential.

2 CHARACTERIZATION

   Since this is a new framework, I start with finding conditions under
   which the constraint set faced by the household is convex to ensure a
   well-behaved household problem.

2.1 Concavity of the Household Problem

   That the constraint set is convex is not obvious because of the
   nonlinear terms
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$pq$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi q$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi p q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , and the functions
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;·<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}(\cdot )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;·<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B(\cdot )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   in the constraints ([168]13)–([169]17). As shown in Section 2.4.1, the
   functions
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B consistent with incentives to repay can take many shapes below an
   upper bound. As a result, it is not difficult to pick functions that do
   not pose a problem for the convexity of the constraint set. So, for
   simplicity, here I focus on
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B constant.

   To ensure that the constraint set faced by the households is convex, it
   is also necessary to restrict the matching function such that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/(\phi \psi )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   is convex in θ. Since ψ and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∈<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;[<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;]<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi \in [0,1]$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   are monotone, one with positive and one with negative slope, this
   property is fairly natural: as θ approaches either zero or infinity,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi \psi$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   tends to zero, so its inverse goes to infinity. In between
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi \psi$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   is larger, so its inverse is smaller. As a result,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/(\phi \psi )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   tends to be u-shaped.

   Notice that key to the argument above is that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi ,
   \psi \le 1$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . While microfounded matching functions satisfy these inequalities
   (such as the urn ball one, which indeed exhibits a convex
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/(\phi \psi )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   ), such inequalities do not hold for some of the matching functions
   used in practice, such as the Cobb–Douglas. Indeed, a Cobb–Douglas
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;f<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;h<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$m=f^\gamma h^{1-\gamma }$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   does not imply
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/(\phi \psi )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   convex for all parameterizations but requires
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0.5<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma \ge 0.5$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . The intuition for
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0.5<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma \ge 0.5$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   goes as follows. In choosing the submarket, buyers face the following
   trade-off: a low p implies a low θ and thus a low ψ. If the price is
   too elastic to θ, a reduction in θ reduces the price so much that
   buyers are likely to choose the submarket with minimum price, that is,
   a corner solution. Using equation ([170]24), it is easy to show that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1-\gamma$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is the elasticity of p to θ. So a high γ ensures a sufficiently low
   elasticity, which in turn ensures convexity of the budget constraint
   and thus an interior solution.

   Proposition 2.If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B are constant and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi (\theta )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   are such that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/(\psi (\theta ) \phi (\theta
   ))$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is a convex function, then the constraint set ([171]13)–([172]17)
   is convex.

   Given the strictly concave preferences, the convexity of the constraint
   set ensures a unique and interior solution to the household's problem
   and it is safe to use first-order conditions, shown in Appendix [173]B,
   to characterize optimal choices.

2.2 Coexistence

   I will now show existence and uniqueness of monetary/nonmonetary
   equilibrium in steady state and for constants
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and B (and for underlying monitoring probabilities that make commitment
   under those constraints incentive compatible as in Proposition [174]1).
   The results, stated in Lemma [175]2 and Proposition [176]3, are
   explained below and illustrated in Figure [177]1. Readers that are not
   so interested in the technical details can jump to the text after
   Proposition [178]3 where Figure [179]1 is explained.
   [180]Details are in the caption following the image
   Fig 1
   [181]Open in figure viewer[182]PowerPoint
   Equilibria Given B.

   From equation ([183]14) it is clear that, since
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$a=0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , an equilibrium is monetary (
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ) iff
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$pq>gt; B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . And since p is normalized to 1, one has to check that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q>gt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Since
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\le \bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   , it follows that monetary equilibrium requires
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}\ge B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   .

   The strategy is this: given a price of bonds
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt;\beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , look for a candidate solution that satisfies all equilibrium
   conditions other than ([184]14). If the equilibrium candidate has
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\ge B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , then that is indeed a monetary equilibrium. It is a monetary
   equilibrium because
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   to satisfy ([185]14), and (as shown in the proof of Proposition [186]3)
   all other equilibrium conditions are unaffected by
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q=B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , then that is a nonmonetary equilibrium because
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m=0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   satisfies ([187]14) and in the proof of Lemma [188]2, it is shown that
   with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt;\beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , ([189]14) cannot be slack. If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q<lt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , then the candidate solution is not an equilibrium because the value
   of money would have to be negative.

   The strategy above works to the extent that given v, there is a unique
   candidate monetary equilibrium q, and this is shown in the following
   lemma. The proof is quite tedious but conceptually it is done in a
   similar fashion as in Brock and Mirman ([190]1972) by showing the
   existence of a unique solution to some key equilibrium conditions. In
   particular, the main difficulty is to show existence of a solution for
   θ. To this aim, Lemma [191]2 requires a technical assumption on the
   matching function: the elasticity
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$- \frac{\phi }{\theta } \frac{\partial
   \theta }{\partial \phi }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   must be decreasing and larger than zero at
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta =0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and below a certain bound for large θ. Intuitively, the restriction
   ensures that ϕ does not go to 0 or to 1 too fast. To see this, notice
   that holding constant
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\frac{\partial \theta }{\partial \phi
   }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   the two limits are satisfied because
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (\theta )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   is decreasing and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi (0)=1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Then, to satisfy the limits, it is required that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\frac{\partial \theta }{\partial \phi
   }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   does not go to 0 or to minus infinity too fast and in the opposite way
   than
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$- \frac{\phi
   }{\theta }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . It is worth stressing that the restriction on these elasticities is a
   sufficient condition, not necessary for the existence of an
   equilibrium.[192]36

   Lemma 2.Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;munder>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̲<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/munder>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\underline{\theta }=0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , and B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   constants and monitoring probabilities smaller than one but high enough
   so that the incentive constraints in Section 2.4.1 are satisfied.
   Furthermore, let the elasticity
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$- \frac{\phi }{\theta } \frac{\partial
   \theta }{\partial \phi }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   be continuous and decreasing with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;lim<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lim _{\theta \rightarrow 0}
   - \frac{\phi }{\theta } \frac{\partial \theta }{\partial \phi
   }>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;lim<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lim _{\theta \rightarrow
   \infty } - \frac{\phi }{\theta } \frac{\partial \theta }{\partial \phi
   }<lt;2+\beta /(v-\beta )$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Then, for each
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt;\beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there is a unique steady-state equilibrium candidate that satisfies
   all equilibrium conditions other than ([193]14). Furthermore, as long
   as constraint
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\le \bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   is slack, the candidate equilibrium has q strictly decreasing in v,
   independent of the limits B, and with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;lim<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;↘<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lim _{v\searrow
   \beta } q=\infty$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   .

   The lemma also reports what happens as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v \rightarrow
   \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   when constraint ([194]13) on q is nonbinding.[195]37 In this case,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\rightarrow
   \infty$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Intuitively, the cost of choosing a market with low price and high q
   is low market tightness θ, low matching probability ψ, and large liquid
   assets. But ending up with liquid assets is not a cost when their
   return approaches that of capital, that is, when
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;↘<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v\searrow \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . So, in this case, agents choose a market with price tending to zero
   and q tending to infinity.[196]38 That q tends to infinity as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v \rightarrow
   \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   implies that there is monetary equilibrium for any bounded B. However,
   with monitoring probabilities that tend to 1, the highest possible
   (“not too tight”) B tends to ∞. So, while monetary equilibrium can be
   constructed (because the debt limit need not be the “not too tight”
   one), there is a nonmonetary equilibrium with the same allocation. In
   this sense, money is not essential with perfect monitoring, confirming
   Wallace ([197]2010). Yet, from an empirical perspective, it is
   interesting that monetary equilibrium can be constructed even with
   arbitrarily large credit.

   Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   be the candidate q given v from the lemma above. As mentioned, the
   candidate equilibrium is a monetary equilibrium, a nonmonetary one, or
   not an equilibrium, depending on ([198]14). This is formalized in the
   proposition below.

   Proposition 3.For each
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt;\beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the candidate steady state in Lemma [199]2 is
     * (i) a monetary equilibrium with
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q=q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       if
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)>gt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       ,
     * (ii) a nonmonetary equilibrium with
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q=q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       if
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)=B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       ,
     * (iii)
       not an equilibrium if
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
       <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)<lt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       .
       Furthermore, there is monetary equilibrium for any
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∈<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;N<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo
       stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v \in (\beta , v^{NM})$<lt;/annotation>gt;
       <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
       where
       [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;N<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt;
       <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;annotation
       encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v^{NM}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
       :MATH]
       is the level of v for which there is nonmonetary equilibrium.

   The proposition is illustrated in Figure [200]1, which plots
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (the increasing and convex function bounded at
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ) and a given constant B (the horizontal line). The unique nonmonetary
   equilibrium given B lies at the intersection between B and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Given B, there is a monetary equilibrium for any
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∈<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;N<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v \in (\beta ,
   v^{NM})$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . For monetary equilibrium, v must be smaller (or the real interest
   rate
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/v-1$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   higher) than the one associated to the nonmonetary equilibrium
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;N<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v^{NM}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   because this way
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m=q(v)-B>gt;0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   . There is no equilibrium for
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;N<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt;v^{NM}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   as in that case,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)<lt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and the value of money would have to be negative. Intuitively, money is
   not demanded if its return is too low, or equivalently, if inflation is
   too high. So there is an upper limit on inflation, which is tighter the
   larger is the debt limit B.

   The figure is shown for the case in which
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}>gt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   . When
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}<lt;B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   , it follows from the proposition that there is no
   monetary equilibrium.

Endogenous productivity, inflation, and velocity

   In Figure [201]1, q is decreasing in v and as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v\rightarrow
   \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\rightarrow
   \infty$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (provided that monitoring probabilities tend to 1 so that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;¯<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\bar{q}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   can go to infinity). Intuitively,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v\rightarrow
   \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is the Friedman Rule, in which case, inflation is negative and money
   gives the same return as capital. As a result there is no private cost
   of not finding goods and holding high liquidity so agents choose a
   market with low θ and low ψ. Instead, inflation prevents θ from going
   to its efficient lower bound because it makes it privately costly to
   hold money. This leads agents to choose markets with higher θ so that
   there is a higher probability of finding a match and spend the money.
   However, the higher the matching probability for a buyer, the lower it
   is for a seller. As shown studying the planning problem, low θ is
   efficient because it implies high ϕ, which can be interpreted as firms
   productivity: through the lens of a neoclassical model, a high ϕ would
   be captured by a higher TFP parameter. So in this model, the Solow
   residual is endogenous and higher, the lower the inflation rate or
   v.[202]39

   The relationship between market tightness θ and endogenous productivity
   highlights the role of demand in this model: there is a social benefit
   if households search in crowded markets (where the ratio of households
   per trading posts is high), because the higher the demand for each
   trading post, the less production is unutilized.

   In this model also, velocity is an endogenous function of θ. Indeed the
   velocity of broad money (i.e., money plus credit such as M1, M2, MZM)
   in this model is ψ. This is because velocity is defined as output over
   broad money, which in this model is equal to q. Since production is
   equal to
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;c<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;δ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$c+k^{\prime }-k(1-\delta )$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , it follows from ([203]15) that velocity is ψ. Intuitively, a change
   in velocity is equivalent to a change in spare spending capacity (i.e.,
   a change in ψ). That velocity is endogenous is interesting because it
   is hard to get velocity to move at all in monetary models. Furthermore,
   Mennuni ([204]2021) builds on this theory and finds it to be promising
   to explain how velocity moves over the business cycle.

2.3 Monetary Equilibrium with Credit Above Income
