   It is now possible to appreciate better a key point of the paper, that
   is, the extent to which money is robust to credit. To this aim, it is
   useful to relate q to income. From equation ([205]16), and using the
   fact that in equilibrium
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p=1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$a=a^{\prime }=0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi mathvariant="normal">gt;Δ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$m^{\prime
   }=m+\Delta m$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , one gets
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} q=(w+rk)/\psi .
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (26)
   Since
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi <lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the equation above shows that q is larger than income
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$w+rk$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , which in turn is equal to aggregate transactions. And since monetary
   equilibrium exists if
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B<lt;q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there are levels of B larger than income or transactions for which
   there is monetary equilibrium.

   In more intuitive terms, in equilibrium aggregate spending must equal
   aggregate income. As a result, if buyers matching probability ψ is
   smaller than 1 so that not all agents get to spend, then those in a
   match must spend more than their income. It follows that, for an
   equilibrium to exist, agents need spending capacity (money + credit) in
   excess of their individual income. As a result, money demand is
   positive even when credit is larger than individual income, but smaller
   than spending. Notice that this result comes from the general
   equilibrium requirement that spending is equal to income in the
   aggregate, which is true with or without insurance. Furthermore, this
   result is true also outside steady state and for any function B that
   has equilibrium: whenever
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B<lt;q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   money has value from ([206]14). This result is important because with B
   larger than income, it is possible to have outside + inside money
   larger than GDP, as in the data.

   Moreover, since as shown in Lemma [207]2,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;lim<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;↘<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lim _{v\searrow
   \beta } q=\infty$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there can be monetary equilibrium for any bounded constant B
   (provided that there is enough monitoring to satisfy incentives not to
   default). So there can be monetary equilibrium as long as credit is not
   infinite. As mentioned, this latter result requires deflation and would
   not hold if agents had to pay vacancy costs proportional to q. In that
   case, q would be finite for any v. Vacancy costs would not change the
   result that there is monetary equilibrium with credit larger than
   income as from ([208]26), since
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≤<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi \le 1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;n<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\ge wn+rk$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   .

   Since the result is a key point of the paper, it is summarized in the
   following corollary.

   Corollary 1.For each
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v>gt; \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the maximum credit limit consistent with monetary equilibrium is
   larger than transactions and equal to
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q(v)$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , which is decreasing in v and tends to infinity as
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;→<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$v\rightarrow
   \beta$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   .

   An intuition for why money is robust to credit larger than income goes
   as follows. Because of the search friction, some agents do not buy
   goods, yet they make income and want a store of value so that they can
   spend it in the future. There are two options: either to lend to other
   buyers, or to buy the fiat asset. If the borrowing limit is large
   enough so that the buyers in a match can borrow not just their own
   income, but also that of the agents that did not make a match, then
   there is no need for a fiat asset. This requires the buyers in a match
   to borrow q. If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B<lt;q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , then not all the income of the unmatched agents can be lent so there
   must be another asset in positive net supply, which on the one hand
   stores the savings of the unmatched and on the other gives to the
   agents in a match the purchasing power to spend for the income of the
   agents not in a match.[209]40

   To summarize, in equilibrium aggregate income equals aggregate
   spending. But since some agents do not get to spend their income, those
   in a match need means to spend more than their income. So the key is
   that agents make income but may not find spending opportunities,
   thereby ending up with “unwanted” liquid savings. This is not the case
   in LW: the CM makes it such that there are no “unwanted” liquid income
   savings and, through a period (DM+CM), each agent spends exactly their
   income. In Shi ([210]1997), the big family assumption is such that each
   family always has income equal to spending. As a result, in these
   frameworks, credit equal to income is enough for money not to
   have value.

An example

   An example helps illustrate how useful money is in this economy. From
   Figure [211]1, it is evident that, given a borrowing limit, monetary
   equilibrium has higher q and lower v (or higher real interest rate
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$1/v-1$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ) than the nonmonetary equilibrium. Production is also smaller in a
   nonmonetary equilibrium relative to a monetary one: if buyers cannot
   store value in the form of the liquid asset, they choose markets where
   it is inefficiently too easy to buy goods, but this hinders firms'
   ability to sell goods leading to a lower production. To illustrate this
   mechanism and show how poor an allocation can be in a nonmonetary
   equilibrium, Proposition [212]4 covers a special case, when the
   borrowing limit is proportional to end-of-period income,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≡<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;K<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B\equiv \gamma (w+rK)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   .

   Of special interest is when
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma =1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . This is a hedge case with a result that is perhaps surprising: in a
   nonmonetary equilibrium with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma =1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , production is zero. The result should become intuitive once one
   recalls what argued in Section [213]2.3, that those in a match must
   spend more than their income for markets to clear when
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi <lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Then, if credit allows each buyer to only spend their end-of-period
   income, a nonmonetary equilibrium must have
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi =1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . But this requires
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∞<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta =\infty$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . As a result, firms face
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ϕ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\phi =0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and do not demand inputs.[214]41

   The result highlights how dramatically bad the nonmonetary allocation
   can be without enough credit relative to a monetary equilibrium where,
   for the same credit limit, production takes place thanks to the extra
   monetary liquidity. For production to take place in a nonmonetary
   equilibrium, γ must be larger than 1. And if
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma <lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there is no nonmonetary equilibrium because the liquidity provided by
   credit is insufficient for an equilibrium without the further liquidity
   provided by money. Intuitively, with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma <lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , credit B is always below q so
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m
   m$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   must be positive from ([215]14).

   Proposition 4.Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≡<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;w<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;K<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B\equiv \gamma (w+rK)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   .

   If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;>gt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma >gt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there is nonmonetary equilibrium with production.

   If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma =1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , no production takes place in a nonmonetary equilibrium.

   If
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma <lt;1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , there is no nonmonetary equilibrium.

   To paraphrase the result, liquidity (money + credit) must be
   sufficiently large to sustain production. The proposition highlights
   how thirsty of liquidity this economy is. In comparison, in transaction
   models where financial transaction is at most equal to income (e.g.,
   Lucas and Stokey [216]1987 and Svensson [217]1985) with
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;γ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\gamma \ge 1$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the economy is saturated with liquidity and there is no
   monetary equilibrium.

Other results

   The model also has many implications that are in common with the new
   monetarist approach. In particular, it can be shown that money is
   neutral but not superneutral, that if B is “lump sum” in the sense that
   it is independent of the households inputs, then credit has no
   implications for the steady state as in GMW. While these results are
   not new, it seems worth mentioning that they hold in this somewhat
   different environment.

3 ACCOUNTING FOR MONETARY AGGREGATES

   In 2020.II, M1 over quarterly GDP was 2.63; the ratio was 3.62 for
   either M2 or M3, and 4.19 for MZM. Furthermore, inside money alone (or
   credit) was larger than GDP. This is because at that time the monetary
   base (or outside money) was equal to 1.02 times GDP. So inside money
   measured, for example, through M2, was
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2.6<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3.62<lt;/mn>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1.02<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$2.6=3.62-1.02$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   times quarterly GDP. That money and credit are larger than GDP is not
   just true during the pandemic. Prior the Covid-19 crisis (e.g.,
   2017.III), inside money M2−MB was
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2.80<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0.79<lt;/mn>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2.01<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$2.80-0.79=2.01$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   times GDP.[218]42 Is it possible to have monetary equilibrium with so
   much liquidity and when credit alone is larger than transactions? It
   has been shown theoretically that there is monetary equilibrium for any
   bounded credit, so the answer is yes. Below, it is shown briefly how
   the model must be parameterized to match these data.

   In this model,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m
   M$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is outside money and B is equal to inside money (a liability of the
   private sector used as a medium of exchange, see Lagos [219]2008), so
   total liquidity, or inside and outside money together, is
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m M+B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . From ([220]14),
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q=p_m M+B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   .[221]43 Furthermore, from the matching function and the fact that
   sales are equal to GDP,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;G<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;D<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;P<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi =GDP/q$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   , so it is possible to parameterize ψ to match the ratio between GDP
   and a measure of total liquidity such as M1, M2, M3, or MZM.[222]44
   Then, it is possible to parameterize B to the amount of inside money to
   match both credit and outside money from ([223]14) so that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q=p_m m+B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   , where m is the monetary base. Such an equilibrium is monetary because
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B<lt;p_m m
   +B=q$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   and it has been argued that whenever
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;<lt;<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$B<lt;q$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the equilibrium is indeed monetary.

   This procedure shows how to parameterize the model so that there is
   monetary equilibrium with the observed amount of money and credit.
   However, it should be emphasized that this requires to pick the
   probability of finding goods ψ (or the parameters of the matching
   function) accordingly: the smaller ψ, the larger liquidity over output.
   For example, to match a very broad measure such as MZM in 2017, one
   needs
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;G<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;D<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;P<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0.33<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi =GDP/(p_m M+B)=0.33$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . One might worry that the number implies an unrealistically too severe
   search friction. However, not all MZM is as liquid as cash so it seems
   unfair to treat it as the inside money in this paper, which is
   perfectly substitutable to cash. Accordingly, one may find a narrower
   aggregate a more appropriate target, leading to a higher ψ: for
   example, to have
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0.9<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi =0.9$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , the monetary aggregate must be 1.1 times quarterly GDP; that number
   lies between M1 and M2 (e.g., M1 and M2 were, respectively, 0.71 and
   2.8 times quarterly GDP in 2017). Furthermore, to match a broad measure
   of money with a milder search friction, one could add search effort (or
   other impediments to spending), thereby inducing a low ψ not because of
   a very low efficiency of the matching function that impedes finding
   spending opportunities, but because of agents' decisions to economize
   on search effort. In quantitative extensions of this model, it would
   also be possible to add goods with very little or no search friction at
   all that are demanded in bounded amounts, such as food and other daily
   needs, or to go in the opposite direction and add financial assets that
   are not as liquid as money, such as government bonds, or even physical
   assets that are as illiquid as housing.

   On top of matching monetary levels, ongoing work suggests that the
   model can also match its movements and offers a promising explanation
   of business cycle fluctuations through the wedge in the matching
   friction. In particular, movements in velocity are notoriously hard to
   match but in a companion paper, Mennuni ([224]2021), it is shown how a
   shock to the matching function moves ψ and therefore GDP over
   liquidity, or velocity. At the same time, a matching shock moves firms'
   matches over production capacity, or measured TFP. The endogenous
   movements in TFP generate the usual real business cycle comovements.
   This way the model accounts for the large movements in velocity,
   capacity utilization, as well as the usual comovements in the real
   variables. That the model accounts for large credit and monetary
   levels, and the business cycle fluctuations of real and monetary
   variables, make it a promising framework for policy analysis.

   Finally, another advantage of this model is that it is possible to
   match monetary aggregates while assuming a shorter length of a period
   such as a day, a week, or a month. A shorter period length than a
   quarter is arguably more appropriate to study monetary issues; the
   relevant period length on which to measure the flow of transactions
   that need to be financed with the existing stock of money is arguably
   fairly short and related to time needed to liquidate the next most
   liquid assets other than money. But in models where credit must be
   smaller than transactions, this is an issue because, in order to have
   monetary equilibrium, it is necessary to take a time horizon such that
   the flow of transactions is larger than the stock of liquidity so that
   the transaction constraint binds. With the data above, this requires a
   period length much larger than a quarter (so that
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;G<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;D<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;P<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$GDP$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   over
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m+B$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is larger than 1). The present model is robust to shorter periods
   provided that the matching probability
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;G<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;D<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;P<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;/<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;M<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;B<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo
   stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\psi =GDP/(p_m M+B)$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   is adjusted to account for the smaller flow of transactions. But that
   the matching probability is an increasing function of time is natural
   with a search friction. Similarly to models of labor search where
   unemployment is a stock and job creation and destruction are flows, to
   the extent that the probability of finding goods is proportional to the
   time length of a period, calibration to a shorter period length
   involves equivalent stands on the underlying search friction.

4 CONCLUSIONS

   Motivated by the observed amounts of monetary holdings in times when
   several means of payment do not require to hold liquid funds, this
   paper developed a theory of liquid assets as a way to store unspent
   available funds that emerge because of a search friction in the goods
   market. Monetary equilibrium is consistent with large availabilities of
   credit, which is key to match the levels of broad monetary quantities
   we observe.

   Money also enhances productivity and welfare: when people are less
   worried about not finding goods because they have easy alternative
   means to store value, they search for better deals (lower prices but
   longer queue length) making firms more productive. Put differently, the
   presence of money increases aggregate demand relative to aggregate
   supply. These implications are different than those of other
   monetary models.

   While the story has elements of popular narratives, the framework is
   novel and could have many uses. For instance, here liquidity can be
   extended to a larger set of assets differing in their liquidity
   (captured by the severity of the search friction, which stands for
   differences in information acquisition costs, risk, maturity, etc.)
   reflecting empirical counterparts ranging from government bonds, equity
   shares, and other financial products, to possibly far less liquid
   assets such as houses.[225]45

   Furthermore, this model may help understand further the role of the
   financial sector. In particular, this framework may suggest an
   alternative to the view that the financial crisis and the prolonged
   stagnation are due to credit constraints. In a sense, the large
   literature that exploits credit constraints building on Bernanke and
   Gertler ([226]1989) and Kiyotaki and Moore ([227]1997) works in the
   opposite way to that in this paper. In these models, during recessions
   firms wish to produce more but are constrained. Here instead, firms do
   not wish to produce more because of their difficulties to sell. These
   two channels are possibly both real but have different policy
   implications. In particular, this paper may explain why policies aimed
   at increasing liquidity may not always work. Easing credit conditions
   can be effective in models with credit-constrained firms but it may not
   be as effective in this model where, owing to the matching friction,
   there can be a lack of “appetite” even when there is enough liquidity.

   The framework may also be useful to study fiscal policy, for instance:
   since TFP is affected by the demand–supply ratio, government spending
   could increase TFP.

   Finally, it is well known that in real life, a lot of liquidity is held
   by firms and corporations but in this model all assets are held by the
   household.[228]46 It would be interesting to study an extension of this
   model with a different decentralization where households buy
   consumption goods while firms trade capital subject to severe search
   frictions reflecting low arrival rates of big investment opportunities
   such as takeovers, thereby generating large holdings of liquid assets.
   In this context, households and firms may also prefer different types
   of assets reflecting their different needs for liquidity. Accounting
   for the liquid assets in the hands of firms may also contribute to the
   growing literature that focuses on the macro-economic implications of
   frictions in the production sector, such as Bigio and La'O ([229]2020)
   among others.

APPENDIX A: EXCHANGE AND CLEARANCE OF BONDS

   At the end of a period, each agent j has a net position of
   intratemporal bonds equal to the ones received by firms (and issued by
   some other household) less those she issued to a firm. Call
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\hat{b}_j$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   the bonds issued by agent j and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\hat{b}_{-j,j}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   the bonds agent j receives by firms (the indexes
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;${-j,j}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   emphasize that the bond is issued by some household other than j, and
   passed on to j). So agent j’s net position is
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\hat{b}_{-j,j}-\hat{b}_{j}$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . The sum of all households’ net positions is
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\sum _j \hat{b}_{-j,j}-\sum _j
   \hat{b}_{j}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . Since firms pass to households all bonds they receive
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;b<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\sum _j \hat{b}_{-j,j}=\sum _j
   \hat{b}_{j}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , that is, the intratemporal bond market clears. Similarly, at the end
   of the period, the household has intertemporal bonds issued in the
   previous period by some other household
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\hat{a}_{-j,j}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   less those she issued
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\hat{a}_j$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt;
   :MATH]
   and
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo>gt;−<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\sum _j \hat{a}_{-j,j}=\sum _j
   \hat{a}_{j}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   . If the net credit position of an individual agent is negative
   (positive), she can pay (be paid) in money or by issuing (accepting)
   the intertemporal bond. Since the intertemporal bond is issued by an
   agent and accepted by an other,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;∑<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mover accent="true">gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̂<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mover>gt; <lt;mi>gt;j<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\sum _j \hat{a}_{j}=0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   .

APPENDIX B: FIRST-ORDER CONDITIONS OF THE HOUSEHOLD

   Let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mtext>gt;…<lt;/mtext>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt;
   <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lambda _1,\ldots,\lambda _4\ge
   0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   be the lagrange multipliers on the constraints ([230]13)–([231]16)
   and let
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\lambda
   _{k^{\prime }},\lambda _{m^{\prime }}, \lambda _{a^{\prime }}, \lambda
   _q, \lambda _p, \lambda _\theta \ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   be the multipliers, respectively, on
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$k^{\prime }\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p_m m^{\prime }\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;munder>gt; <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;̲<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/munder>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$ a^{\prime }\ge
   \underline{a}$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$q\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;0<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$p\ge 0$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   ,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;≥<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;munder>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;̲<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/munder>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$\theta \ge \underline{\theta
   }$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   , with complementary slackness between each multiplier and the
   respective constraint. The households' first-order condition for c,
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$k^{\prime
   },m^{\prime },a^{\prime },q,p$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   are
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;u<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;c<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} u_c=\lambda _3,
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B1)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="badbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;k<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;E<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">gt; <lt;msubsup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;r<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3<lt;/mn>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;δ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \lambda _3-\lambda
   _{k^{\prime }}=\beta E{\left(\lambda _4^{\prime } r^{\prime }+\lambda
   _3^{\prime }(1-\delta ) \right)}, \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt;
   <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B2)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="badbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;E<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")"
   open="(" separators="">gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msubsup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="goodbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;m<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt;
   <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \lambda
   _{4}p_m-\lambda _{m^{\prime }}=\beta E{\left((\lambda _2^{\prime }+
   \lambda _4^{\prime })p_m^{\prime } \right)},
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B3)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;v<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="badbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;msup>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;a<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msup>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;β<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;E<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">gt;
   <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;msubsup>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mo>gt;′<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/msubsup>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \lambda _{4}v-\lambda
   _{a^{\prime }}=\beta E{\left(\lambda _2^{\prime }+ \lambda _4^{\prime }
   \right)}, \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B4)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="badbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mn>gt;2<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;,<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation}
   (\lambda _3-\lambda _4 p){\left(\psi +\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial
   \theta }\frac{\partial \theta }{\partial q}q\right)}=\lambda _1+\lambda
   _2 p -\lambda _q-\lambda _\theta \frac{\partial \theta }{\partial q},
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B5)
   [MATH: <lt;semantics>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;2<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo
   linebreak="badbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;=<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;ψ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt;
   <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;(<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;3<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;−<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mn>gt;4<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mo stretchy="false">gt;)<lt;/mo>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mo linebreak="goodbreak">gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;mfenced close=")" open="("
   separators="">gt; <lt;msub>gt; <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mo>gt;+<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;msub>gt;
   <lt;mi>gt;λ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/msub>gt; <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;θ<lt;/mi>gt;
   <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;mrow>gt; <lt;mi>gt;∂<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;mi>gt;p<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;/mfenced>gt;
   <lt;mfrac>gt; <lt;mn>gt;1<lt;/mn>gt; <lt;mi>gt;q<lt;/mi>gt; <lt;/mfrac>gt; <lt;mo>gt;.<lt;/mo>gt; <lt;/mrow>gt; <lt;annotation
   encoding="application/x-tex">gt;$$\begin{equation} \lambda _2+\lambda
   _4\psi =\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial \theta }\frac{\partial \theta
   }{\partial p}(\lambda _3 -\lambda _4 p)+{\left(\lambda _p+\lambda
   _\theta \frac{\partial \theta }{\partial p}\right)}\frac{1}{q}.
   \end{equation}$$<lt;/annotation>gt; <lt;/semantics>gt; :MATH]
   (B6)

   These first-order conditions and the other conditions listed in the
   definitions of equilibrium (two or three depending on whether the
   equilibrium is monetary or not) fully characterize equilibrium.

Biography

     * Alessandro Mennuni is at University of Southampton (E-mail:
       [232][email protected]).

   LITERATURE CITED
     * Aiyagari, S.Rao. (1994) “Uninsurable Idiosyncratic Risk and
       Aggregate Savings.” Quarterly Journal of Economics, 109, 659–684.
     * Alvarez, Fernando, and Urban J. Jermann. (2000) “Efficiency,
       Equilibrium, and Asset Pricing with Risk of Default.” Econometrica,
       68, 775–797.
     * Alvarez, Fernando, and Francesco Lippi. (2009) “ Financial
       Innovation and the Transactions Demand for Cash.” Econometrica.
       77(2).

       of Monetary Economics, 60, 383–390.

       Interventions in Credit Markets.” Journal of Economic Theory, 178,
       455–487.

       Demand Shocks as Productivity Shocks.” Mimeo.

       (2007) “Money, Credit and Banking.” Journal of Economic Theory,
       135, 171–195.

       and Business Fluctuations.” American Economic Review, 79, 14–31.
     * Bethune, Zachary, Tai-Wei Hu, and Guillaume Rocheteau. (2018)
       “Indeterminacy in Credit Economies.” Journal of Economic Theory,
       175, 556–584.
     * Bigio, Saki, and Jennifer La'O. (2020) “Distortions in Production
       Networks.” Quarterly Journal of Economics, 135, 2187–2253.
     * Brock, William A., and Leonard J. Mirman. (1972) “Optimal Economic
       Growth and Uncertainty: The Discounted Case.” Journal of Economic
       Theory, 4, 479–513.

       of Money.” CEPR Discussion Papers 11444.

       Outside Money as Alternative Media of Exchange.” Journal of Money,
       Credit and Banking, 31, 443–457.

       The New York Times Magazine.

       Frictions for Business Cycles.” Discussion Papers 1402, Centre for
       Macroeconomics. (CFM).

       Equilibrium in Monetary Economies.” Journal of Economic Theory,
       136, 709–718.

       Recessions.” NBER working papers, National Bureau of Economic
       Research, Inc.

       Exchange. London: Appleton and Co.

       Theory with Non-Degenerate Distributions.” Journal of Economic
       Theory, 148, 2266–2312.

       Political Economy, 105, 385–411.

       Creation and Job Destruction in the Theory of Unemployment.” Review
       of Economic Studies, 61, 397–415.

       Liquidity, Vol. 1. Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press.

       Macroeconomic Dynamics in a Model of Goods, Labor and Credit Market
       Frictions.” IZA Discussion Papers 5763.
